model_solution:
Step 1:  Begin by simplifying the equation and rewriting the terms to make it easier to solve. $4x^{1/3}-2 \cdot \frac{x}{x^{2/3}}=7+\sqrt[3]{x}$ becomes $4x^{1/3}-2x^{1-\frac{2}{3}}=7+x^{1/3}$
Step 2: $4x^{1/3}-2x^{1/3}=7+x^{1/3}\Rightarrow 2x^{1/3}=7+x^{1/3}$
Step 3: $2x^{1/3}-x^{1/3}=7$
$2x^{1/3}=7 \Rightarrow x^{1/3}=\frac{7}{2}$
Step 4: $x^{1/3} = \frac{7}{2} \Rightarrow \left(x^{1/3}\right)^3 = \left(\frac{7}{2}\right)^3 \Rightarrow x = \frac{343}{8}$
$\left(x^{1/3}\right)^3 = \left(\frac{7}{2}\right)^3 \Rightarrow x = \frac{343}{8}$
Step 5: $\left(x^{1/3}\right)^3 = \left(\left(\frac{7}{2}\right)^3\right) \Rightarrow x = \frac{343}{8}$
$x = \frac{343}{8}$
$ x = \frac{343}{8} $
$x^{1/3} = \frac{7}{2} \Rightarrow x = \left(\frac{7}{2}\right)^3$
steps: Step 1:  Begin by simplifying the equation and rewriting the terms to make it easier to solve. $4x^{1/3}-2 \cdot \frac{x}{x^{2/3}}=7+\sqrt[3]{x}$ becomes $4x^{1/3}-2x^{1-\frac{2}{3}}=7+x^{1/3}$
full_steps: Step 1:  Begin by simplifying the equation and rewriting the terms to make it easier to solve. $4x^{1/3}-2 \cdot \frac{x}{x^{2/3}}=7+\sqrt[3]{x}$ becomes $4x^{1/3}-2x^{1-\frac{2}{3}}=7+x^{1/3}$
